results.title: World Class De-Forestation
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: A look at the damaging effects of the de-forestation occurring in the East Gippsland forest ranges and the efforts of a group of activists to stop it. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Watch the Gap
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: A sometimes-humorous report on Pine Gap and its strategic use against US military enemies. It also examines the efforts of the Nuclear Disarmament Party to uncover what exactly Pine Gap is being used for. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Violence is Violence
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: A report on the concerns over the private toll road which was built at the expense of over 2 hectares of public parkland in inner Sydney. Hundreds of Sydney residents take over the streets to protest car-dominated public space and offer a vision of urban sustainability. Their celebration is met with a brutal police response. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV

results.title: Fire, Water, Earth
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: A report on the environmental damage that the Western Mining Corporation is causing to the Arabunna people by the siphoning of 42 million litres of water a day from the Great Artesian Basin. The world’s largest uranium mine is located at Roxby Downs in South Australia. It is owned by multinational mining corporation WMC and is built on Arabunna and Kokotha land. This story follows the nuclear trail from an occupation of a WMC borefield by Arabunna elder Kevin Buzzacott and his supporters to a daring mission by videoactivists into the heart of WMC headquarters in Melbourne, surprising the boss himself.Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV

results.title: Nice time
results.brief_description: An observation of couples and youths at night around London’s famous Piccadilly Circus. Influenced by the Free Cinema movement, Claude Goretta and Alain Tanner allow the camera to observe the scenes of people milling in front of cinemas, walking around the Circle and attempting to get into night clubs. There is no voice over, and instead, it is the observational mise-en-scene and the almost relaxed detachment of the observing camera that creates a leisurely but intriguing glimpse into everyday pleasure and life. The decision of the Swiss directors, Goretta and Tanner, to travel to the UK to involve themselves in Free Cinema was an indication of the immense influence the movement was having on documentary filmmaking, an influence that was to lead to the radical aesthetics of “cinema verite”.
